This is something the critics and most viewers don't understand about this movie series.  It's profoundly silly and they knew what they were making was profoundly silly.  The movie owns the silliness of the plot.  Where other profoundly silly plots take themselves way to seriously to be, this knows what it is and it has fun with it.  Not sure why some of the "babies" were dubbed.  The Bastidas twins who plays Rosita in the movie was 5 years at the time of the movie was made and her mouth was not altered by CGI, because the CGI was pretty weak.  So why couldn't she do her own talking?  Sure it's dumb but it's not suppose to be anything but dumb fun for kids.  Let the kids have some dumb fun.

Slightly better actin' and a twist that's unpredictable but not nonsensical don't really do much to make "Superbabies: Baby Geniuses 2" a sequel that's gonna delight anyone but actual infants who don't know any better. Because, try as the filmmakers might, babies CAN'T act so all they can do is put bad superimposed lips of different actors over theirs and replace them with little people in costumes for terrible, even by family-friendly standards, fight scenes. Please, don't waste your time with this second misguided attempt at bringin' a copyright-friendly "Rugrats" to life.

Superbabies is a beautiful blend of action and comedy. The fact that the heroes are babies only adds to the movies pure brilliance. The story is quite unique and is something you wouldn't expect in a kid-friendly comedy like this. It has many twists and turns for a mature adult to enjoy, and enough Morgan Freeman so the kids can follow along. The jokes consist of funny references the adults will love, with some potty jokes thrown in (not enough to disgust the adults though) so the kids can have a laugh too. Each of the characters are likable and have unique personalities. Each of the characters has a deep backstory that is gone into at certain points in the film. The film gives enough attention to each of the characters and I found myself looking forward to when each of the characters would get a moment of focus. To make a long review short; Superbabies is an amazing film that will easily be your kid's favorite film, and is also a film you'll find yourself enjoying a lot.

I came into this knowing it had been touted as the worst movie of all time (see IMDB's Bottom 100 list), but as I committed to watching it with a bunch of friends while indulging in a few beverages, the main question I had was "Will it at least be ENJOYABLY bad?". And although it isn't a masterpiece of awesomely awful film like THE ROOM is, I can honestly answer "yes". Just don't consider watching it alone and sober. The effects are terrible (and strangely disturbing in parts), the plot jumps all over the place while making very little sense, the dialogue is as bad as you'd expect, and most importantly Jon Voight gives one of the most bizarrely over-the-top performances ever. But I had a wonderful time laughing AT the film. The only genuinely positive thing I could say is that there were 1 or 2 moments that I thought maybe the laughs were intended by the film-makers, but they were few and far between. My suggestion? Get your mates, get some drinks, and have a Superbabies Drinking Game Night. Just drink whenever the character, Kahuna, is mentioned by name (it's a lot!).

I can never look at "A Christmas Story" in the same way again, thanks to this goddamned movie. What can even be said about it, other than it has a couple of ideas in it which could have been, under very, VERY different circumstances, used in an interesting way? Jon Voight further proves that he should give up his Oscar (he puts on a completely fake German accent, and generally goes through the motions, which are humiliating ones), while the rest of the cast prove they should never get work again. Whoopi Goldberg makes a cameo--whether it's more embarrassing than her being in THEODORE REX or not would require me to see that film, and that's not bloody likely. The special effects are appallingly crude; the babies' lips, while digitally manipulated, still don't remotely sync up with the dialogue, but the dialogue is terrible anyway, so it's no great loss. Gregory Poppen's script is rambling and incoherent, and Bob Clark's (director of the aforementioned "A Christmas Story") direction is anonymous and spiritless. The child actors seem hardly to have been aware they were in a film at all, which is just as well; Skyler Shaye and Justin Chatwin play a teen couple, who are so dull as to have nothing worth saying about them. Deren Abram's production design fails by giving the Kahuna (the "hero") a secret lair which appears completely uncongenial to habitation, especially for children; it's a combination of THE NEVER-ENDING STORY and WILLY WONKA, but without charm or imagination. A spark of interest is raised when it is shown that the Kahuna pets and companions are almost all holograms; the loneliness of this situation could have been profitably used in a better film. But this is not that film, it is a dull, incoherent, crass, and intellectually offensive one. It's scarcely worth watching even for bad-movie lovers.

there are many words i could use to describe this movie. there are many words i could use to describe my feelings after watching this movie. i am trying not to use foul language, but i might have to later on in this review, as i really have an intense hatred for this movie. all i can really say is that if you have ever heard of this movie, you have probably heard how god-awful it is. god-awful would be an eternal improvement though. bob clark was the director of this movie. he was known for his raunchy 80's comedies porky's and its sequel. those were the two of the earliest college comedies to ever be recognized. they were hilarious and spawned many clones. and then after a whole handful of other movies no one has ever heard of, out comes baby geniuses, which was an absolutely terrible movie that garnered some really bad reviews. i was not impressed in the least. then bob clark's last film comes out. this was his LAST film. what a way to go, mr. clark. from pioneering the world of comedy to pioneering the world of s**t. there, i swore. again, with this film, they have talented stars in it, well actually just jon voight. all the rest suck already. this movie is an abomination to the film industry. this makes me say something that i might not say on any other film. this was equally as bad as manos: the hands of fate. there are absolutely no redeeming qualities about this. nothing can explain the inherent torture i went through subjecting myself to this. at one point, i had to pause this and walk around outside for some fresh air after almost getting sick at the waste of comedy. the same jokes were used in this movie as was in the original. why would anyone let them make a sequel??? let alone make a SECOND SEQUEL???? yeah, there's another one of these slated for release soon. its like the people behind date movie, epic movie, and disaster movie. DO YOU NOT REALIZE THAT YOU ARE FAILING MISERABLY AT WHAT YOU DO???!!!!! watching this movie might make you think of a question to ask me. why would i watch this? why would i subject myself to pain and torture? because i am a movie critic and it is my job to warn you of how entirely detestable, abhorrent, heinous, and ungodly these kinds of movies are. i had to look up synonyms for bad things to describe my feelings. never watch this, please.

TERRIBLE! Absolutely Terrible. With a concept that seems to have been the product of a particularly potent evening of narcotic abuse, Super Babies is easily one of the worst films ever made. Director Bob Clark, who specializes is producing this sort of bullshit ideas, tries to sell us a world in which babies are actually super intelligent beings who hold webcam conversations with the President of the U.S. and N'Sync. It's that bad. 

Add the two wooden teenagers, the Scooby-Dooesque villain and the unconvincing "dramatic" moments and you've got the formula for disaster. How the hell does Bob Clark get the funding for this kind of schlock? What is his secret? Perhaps I could be a movie director as well. Avoid this movie like the plague.

In the beginning, it all just seemed like some beautiful, horrible dream...
 
It was nearly two years ago now that I first heard of the film that would become [i]Superbabies: Baby Geniuses 2[/i].  You see, Access Hollywood was on right before Survivor (and still probably is, though I've mostly given up on Survivor since it started sucking so royally) and I'd gotten into the habit of watching it so my blood could get good and angried.  "THAT'S NOT FRIGGING NEWS," I'd scream at Pat O'Brien, deaf to my pleading to stop, "YOU SHOULD ALL BE SHOT AND KILLED!"
 
But it was Access Hollywood that first brought me into the world of [i]Superbabies[/i].  They did a behind-the-scenes report on it, and interviewed star Scott Baio.  The next morning, I had to convince myself that it wasn't a dream.  Nobody would believe me that such a film could possibly exist.  "Yeah, it's a sequel to [i]Baby Geniuses[/i], but this time the babies are superheroes, and Scott Baio's in it!"  
 
Just look at that last sentence.  It's crazy talk.  I'm amazed I wasn't locked up.
 
Then, a good deal of time later, ads for Superbabies: Baby Geniuses 2 started appearing on billboards and on the sides of buses.  This was no dream.  This was real.  And it was coming to theaters no less, not dumped to video inconspicuously where nobody would notice a desperate Oscar-winning actor (Jon Voight), a one-time next-big-thing (Vanessa Angel) and TV's "Chachie" cavorting with infants made to look like they have superpowers thanks to bad CGI.  
 
How could such a thing be?  How could such a cinematic monster possibly exist, much less be foisted upon hundreds of thousands of unsuspecting moviegoers?
 
Two words: David Paul.
 
These two words may not mean anything to you, nor should they.  But David Paul is the producer of [i]Superbabies[/i].  He's also the producer of the original [i]Baby Geniuses[/i], Anthony Michael Hall's directorial debut[i] Hail Caesar[/i], the Paul Rodriguez vehicle [i]A Million to Juan[/i], and his own ego projects, including the intolerable [i]Slapstick of Another Kind[/i] (Jerry Lewis does sci-fi!) and the even more intolerable[i] Eternity[/i] (Jon Voight does... er, eternity!).  He got his "start" (after producing [i]Falling in Love Again[/i]) at 17 directing [i]Slapstick[/i], a film financed by his family.
 
In other words, David Paul comes from a very, very rich family that can afford to make horrible, horrible movies that nobody would ever, ever want to see and have them get released.  
 
In fact, he'd make a much better super-villain than Jon Voight in [i]Superbabies[/i], an incompetent German intent on taking over the world (probably) using hidden signals in an idiotic kid's TV program hosted by a poorly-made-up toad that he plans to introduce by showing it in the middle of a park, sponsored by a tiny day care center, run by Baio and Angel.  All of this is just plan nonsensical and stupid, and I haven't even mentioned the damn Superbabies yet.
 
See, Voight's brother is a kid named Kahuna, who took some secret formula designed by their father and now doesn't age (he's actually in his 70's, thought he looks 8) and has super powers, a secret chamber and lots of gadgets that do things that don't make a damn bit of sense.
 
Yes, Kahuna.  I don't know why either.  I guess kids today love references to surf movies of the '60s.
 
So the toddler son of Baio and Angel, along with three other kids at the day care that don't seem to have parents, teams up with Kahuna, who, thanks to his weird science gizmos, manages to give them superpowers.  There's Captain Courage, who is strong, Miss Cupid, who causes men to turn gay, Bouncing Boy, who makes DC Comics sue the filmmakers, and Brain Boy, who has the amazing ability to stand around and let other people kick bad guys in the crotch.
 
While the talking babies aren't as horrifyingly creepy as that of the first film (and nowhere near the nightmare-inducing blasphemy-against-all-that-is-right that was the dancing baby of "Ally McBeal"), there's still no effort to make the kids look like they're even coming close the emotions expressed in their dialogue.  The "gags" basically consist of babies saying catch-phrases (only with the word "diaper" in there somewhere), though it's to the filmmaker's credit that there aren't that many poop and fart jokes.
 
Of course, when that filmmaker is Bob Clark, the once-respected man behind [i]A Christmas Story, Black Christmas, Murder by Decree[/i] and [i]Deathdream[/i]... ugh.
 
Just, ugh, Bob.  Ugh.  Still, I know you need a check.
 
To their credit, Baio and Angel only embarass themselves during the opening scene when they're forced to spew some awful expository dialogue.  They leave that up to Voight, who forces out a performance that makes his role in [i]Anaconda[/i] look restrained.  The kids... well, none of the kids will probably ever be seen again.  I mean, have you seen Jonathan Lipnicki lately?  What the hell is up with [i]him[/i]?
 
Sorry, getting distracted.  Watching [i]Superbabies[/i] has caused my brain to melt.  Needless to say, unless you're under 9 (in I.Q. points, not age) or an undiscriminating pedophile, there's no reason ever to expose yourself to this.  I knew about it, and that should have been enough for me, but noooooooo, I had to go prove that I could handle it.  
 
I am [i]such[/i] an idiot.
Never see this movie at all!
